15.17.text: Good Morning TedX San Diego! Hey!

20.58.text:
Today, I want to talk to you
about one of the great loves of my life

24.19.text: which is the love of possibility.

26.53.text:
And what I mean by that
is the passion that you have inside of you

29.95.text:
to create the results that you know
you are meant to create in this world.

34.30.text:
In order to do that, I want to share
with you a little bit about my journey

38.16.text:
of going from being a homeless person
on the streets of New York City

41.88.text:
and transforming my life
and going on to Harvard.

44.44.text:
And another piece I want
to share with you...

46.69.text:
Actually, to start that conversation
is to talk to you a bit today

50.92.text:
about one of my heroes,
who is someone who has passed away

53.82.text:
who was with us as a young man
and his name was Ben Underwood.

57.89.text:
Ben Underwood is someone
who became famous to us in this world

61.64.text:
because he was someone
who we labeled as blind,

64.85.text:
but he actually had the ability
to see in a different way.

71.75.text:
which you've heard about before
with dolphins and bats.

75.17.text:
He, like some people who don't have sight,
found a way to create sound waves.

80.82.text:
He would --you know,
some people pound their foot --

83.44.text:
he would actually use a clicking noise
in his mouth to send sound waves

86.87.text: bouncing off the walls around him

89.04.text:
so that he could actually
navigate his way around the world.

92.04.text:
I know it sounds crazy,
but if you go on YouTube

94.43.text:
you can see tons of videos of Ben
navigating his way around

97.65.text: even though he had actually no eyes.

100.40.text:
And he's an incredible person
to me for a few reasons.

103.42.text:
And one is I would watch
these videos of Ben

106.66.text:
and be so moved by him
because any day of the week

109.83.text:
that you went to his house,
you could watch Ben

113.09.text:
and you would not be able to tell
that he was blind.

115.60.text:
You would watch him run up 
and down the stairs in his home.

118.49.text:
His mother, Aquanetta,
would call down to him,

120.67.text:
and he would get her things
from her dresser upstairs,

123.70.text:
he would ride his bike
around the neighborhood.

125.92.text: He would hold the door open for people

127.75.text:
because he was able to make a noise
that sounded a little like this,

132.77.text:
send sound waves off
and essentially see in a different way.

135.66.text: Now, scientists became fascinated by Ben.

138.35.text: They came from everywhere to study him.

140.46.text:
You would see scientists, and academics,
and reporters that would gather around Ben

144.99.text:
and they would put him
through a series of tests,

147.38.text:
and you would watch them put
a telephone on the table,

151.67.text:
or a plate, or something,
and he would click

153.79.text:
and he would be able to tell you
what was in front of him.

156.57.text: People became fascinated by Ben's story,

158.64.text:
but that's not what moved me
so much about Ben's story.

161.62.text:
There was something else
that was different about Ben

165.65.text:
Now as much as I understand
that people are fascinated at the result

169.89.text:
that he accomplished in his life,
which was, let's be straight,

174.14.text:
what I was curious about in watching him
was what is the thinking

177.75.text:
that gets somebody to create
that kind of result in their lives?

181.21.text:
What is it inside of a person
that refuses to say:

187.89.text:
The answer to that question
is something that moved me

191.17.text: to tears when I learned about Ben's story.

193.26.text:
And what that is, was
a conversation that took place

195.78.text:
between Ben and his mother
the day of his surgery.

198.95.text:
Now, he was two weeks shy
of his third birthday,

201.23.text:
and his mother had put him through
intense chemotherapy

204.43.text: because he had had cancer in both eyes.

206.70.text: And, she had a choice to make:

208.67.text:
"Do I give Ben a ton of chemotherapy
and keep risking his life

214.46.text: Or do I remove his eyes entirely?

216.60.text:
And if I do, he'll live,
but he'll have no sight."

219.54.text:
She made the tough call.
They removed his eyes.

221.99.text:
And, I'll ask you, to imagine
for one moment, if you could,

225.24.text: what you would say to your three year old

227.25.text:
if they woke up from surgery
without their eyes?

231.13.text:
So I listened carefully to the words
his mother Aquanetta chose to share.

236.58.text:
as soon as Ben woke up
and said, "Mom, I can't see,"

239.03.text:
she immediately said to him,
"Ben, yes, you can."

241.95.text:
And in his own words, she said,
"I took his little hands

245.40.text:
and I placed them on my cheeks and I said,
"Ben you can see with your hands."

252.47.text:
and I gave him my arm,
and I let him smell my skin.

255.69.text:
And she said: "Ben, you can smell my skin,
and you can see with your smell."

259.43.text: And then I whispered in his ear:

261.49.text:
"Ben, you can absolutely see.
You can see with your ears."

264.98.text:
And one, two, three, Aquanetta, 
his mother, went through the various ways

270.01.text:
And so, in teaching Ben to refuse
to label himself as blind,

274.26.text:
she set his mind in motion
in the search of a greater possibility.

279.16.text:
He began to ask himself
not " Why can't I see?",

282.29.text: but "In what ways can I see?"

284.74.text:
And for the love and the passion of 
that possibility, he searched for his own

288.63.text:
and therefore it would only make sense
that he would create a new way.

292.15.text: That's what inspires me about him.

293.94.text:
Is when someone is so moved by
what possibility can create in their lives

298.52.text:
- and don't get me wrong,
I marvel at his results,

301.62.text: the fact that he could have echolocation,

304.20.text:
and that people would sit there
and study him is incredible -

307.41.text:
but what moved me to tears again
is the search for another possibility.

311.11.text:
I relate to that in my own life
because well, you guys know,

315.03.text:
that at some point, I ended up
homeless in my life.

317.50.text:
And that happened 
becauseI grew up in the Bronx

321.71.text: My parents had always used drugs,

324.41.text:
I mean, my whole life
they had been getting high.

327.04.text:
And it was commonplace in my household
to walk and see my parents

330.91.text: shooting up drugs in my kitchen.

333.46.text:
And growing up, even though
they were very loving to us,

336.21.text:
my sister and I, I watched them
use drugs so frequently

339.49.text:
that that was just the way
that our lives went.

342.12.text:
That went on for so long.
You can't live like that forever.

347.08.text: Eventually, both my parents contracted HIV

349.53.text:
and by the time I was that age
that most people are

352.21.text:
when they're planning their prom
or applying to college,

356.24.text: what happened in my life, instead,

358.18.text:
was that my mother was without access
to the medications they have now.

361.80.text:
She went from having HIV
to full blown AIDS.

364.44.text:
My father was living
in a homeless shelter.

366.98.text:
I found myself, at 15 years old,
sleeping in New York City streets,

373.16.text:
Many nights I would fall asleep
with my backpack in my lap,

376.39.text:
and I would have 
my journal, my clothing,

379.87.text:
I had a picture of my mother
when she was my age,

382.39.text:
and she was homeless
in New York City

384.50.text: when her family had fallen apart.

386.40.text:
Now living this way, I know
I sound pretty different from other people

390.86.text: because it's such an intense situation,

393.12.text:
but I actually think I was really
just like everyone else.

396.20.text:
No matter what was in front of me,
I had dreams that I wanted to accomplish.

402.15.text:
I had things like I wanted to go to
school, to have a family, a better life.

407.13.text:
But, you know, people listen
when they hear my story

409.82.text:
and I guess much like Ben,
when they study his echolocation,

412.91.text:
they want him to be able to distinguish
the telephone from the computer,

416.41.text: or whatever they did with him,

417.99.text:
people would often ask me
very strange questions

422.12.text:
People would ask me,
"Did you eat from the trash?"

426.79.text:
The things that people
are interested in, fascinate me.

429.57.text:
When instead, what really
was in my heart, was probably

432.60.text:
the most amazing experience I had,
was again, this internal experience.

437.08.text:
I had these dreams,
but living in that kind of despair,

440.86.text: I let them began to fade away.

443.50.text: Have you ever felt hopeless in your life?

445.78.text:
Where you had something 
that you wanted to do

448.53.text: but it felt so much out of your reach?

450.69.text:
I had this voice in the back of my head
that I believe we all have.

454.40.text: I call it the 'what if?' voice.

456.36.text:
And the what if voice said,
"What if you go to school?

459.47.text:
What if you change your life?
What if you go back?"

462.00.text:
And I let that voice fade
in all of this sadness that I was in.

465.45.text:
And there is a quote
that I love by Dr. Martin Luther King:

472.13.text:
the day you become silent
about things that matter."

475.08.text: And feeling that inside of me,

477.45.text:
that was the most dangerous thing
about being in my situation,

482.22.text:
I had a transformational experience.
Unfortunately, it came through tragedy.

485.98.text: It was when my mother died.

487.40.text:
But when she passed away,
what my mother did for me,

490.47.text:
and maybe it was the intense love
that we had for each other

493.80.text:
because we loved each other so much,
her dying, it unlocked my mind

498.86.text:
to begin to think 
of possibility in my own life.

501.80.text:
And the best way I know 
how to explain this

504.16.text:
is there was something about knowing
that at one moment I had a family,

507.86.text:
I had my mother,
and then I lost everything.

510.10.text:
And I realized that life changed
pretty rapidly for the worst.

513.75.text: But life changed. Life can change.

516.60.text:
And I was inspired by this belief
that my life could, in fact, change.

520.30.text:
With that thinking in mind, I remember
knocking on doors in high schools.

524.52.text:
I'd dust myself off
after sleeping on the train,

526.84.text:
I'd knock on doors at high schools
after years of being truant,

530.32.text: and I would ask them to accept me.

532.10.text:
I should have been applying to college;
I was applying to high school,

536.47.text:
I was knocking on doors
asking for them to accept me.

539.01.text:
I went from school, to school, to school,
and I experienced a lot of rejections.

542.80.text: But there was this feeling in my heart,

545.00.text:
that I want so badly to transfer
to everyone that I meet now,

547.92.text: which is that passion that I felt

550.55.text:
for that "What would happen 
if I just kept going?

553.84.text:
Even if there was every evidence
in the world that it wouldn't work out,

559.18.text:
And for the idea that even though
it was unlikely after being told no

562.63.text:
so many times, it was possible
that the next school would accept me.

566.75.text:
And so I continued to knock 
on doors. Until I was accepted.

570.07.text:
And then I fell in love
with what would be possible

572.78.text:
if I got straight A's
for the first time in my life?

576.45.text:
And then I fell in love
with what would be possible

580.49.text:
And I fell in love
with what would be impossible

582.76.text:
with applying for a scholarship
from the New York Times.

586.47.text: And I had no idea how big this would get.

588.57.text:
I didn't know that I would
actually be able to lift myself

591.64.text:
out of homeless, go on to Harvard,
graduate and entirely change my life.

596.67.text:
Like Ben, who I mentioned
in the beginning,

599.82.text:
people get pretty fixated
and fascinated on the result.

604.44.text:
Or, "Talk to me about the mechanics
of how you did what you did."

608.96.text:
But what I am moved by instead is falling
in love with possibility in your life.

613.88.text:
Because haven't you ever felt
in a place of despair?

616.95.text:
You had a goal, you had something
you wanted to accomplish,

619.92.text:
and you started feeling
that fading feeling.

622.91.text: In fact, I love when people talk to youth

625.06.text: because you know what they will often say?

627.09.text:
I always hear people say: "It's great
you have all the passion you have.

630.62.text: Get it done while you're young."

632.33.text:
Raise your hand if anyone's ever told you
'youth' or 'uniquely qualified.'

638.73.text:
And so I hear this with youth,
and I always thought

641.27.text:
that sounded kind of screwy
because what's the implication?

644.14.text:
That one day in your life,
you will no longer be passionate.

647.65.text: You will no longer be capable.

651.33.text:
absolutely no one knows
what's possible

655.94.text:
And each and every moment
is always another chance.

659.16.text:
No matter what your history is,
no matter where you've come from,

663.02.text: every moment is a new possibility.

665.94.text:
And if I could leave you with something,
I'll tell you that as I moved

669.25.text:
through these obstacles in my life,
I was tempted so much

673.43.text:
to think that because of my past
I could not change my future,

676.88.text: but that feeling of, "OK, I'll let it go.

679.49.text: What will happen if I apply to school?

682.02.text:
What will happen if I apply
to the scholarship?

684.82.text:
What will happen if I put 
one foot in front of the other

687.63.text: until my world changes around me?"

689.64.text:
So any time that you are hunkered down
in that feeling of despair,

693.89.text:
any time that you may ever doubt yourself
or believe for a second

697.06.text:
that there was a before, an after,
to your potential in this world,

700.70.text:
I'm standing here today to tell you
that your potential is timeless.

705.17.text:
And will you do this with me now?
As I leave here?

707.86.text:
Will you go, 'new moment,
new opportunity'? Do it with me now.

711.87.text:
New moment, new opportunity.
New moment, new opportunity.

715.90.text:
And one more time,
new moment, new opportunity.

719.62.text: Your potential in this world is timeless.

723.12.text:
My wish for you is that you fall
in love with possibility,

726.31.text:
and you marvel in what it will create
in your life and in this world.

729.90.text:
Thank you so much
for having me here today.
